title: How many vehicles will Tesla deliver to customers in the first half of 2021?
preds: UBS analysts forecast 195,000 vehicles in Q2. 184,000 delivered in Q1 = 379,000 vehicles. Only question is whether there are supply chain or logistical issues with delivering that many vehicles so holding out 1/20 for those.

Tesla already delivered more than 150,000 vehicles in Q1 https://ir.tesla.com/press-release/tesla-q1-2021-vehicle-production-deliveries Tesla forecast >50% annual growth in Q1: "Over a multi-year horizon, we expect to achieve 
50% average annual growth in vehicle deliveries. In some years we may grow faster, which we expect to be the case in 
2021." So if that is evenly distributed expect to see ~380,000 New factories: Gigafactory Berlin does not start production until > July 1; Gigafactory Texas "late 2021" There's a chip shortage, but their Q1 earnings claimed Tesla could switch to a different microcontroller. There was a fire in the Fremont factory in March (although that factory has had four fires in four years, 2014-2018.)
The first outcome has seemingly already been shown to be false, and with that setup the second is utterly unlikely.

It looks like they will deliver a lot, apparently they delivered 188K in Q1, so probably they'll hit 350, but I am only like 85% confident.  That's not a HUGE margin for error, and some things could lower their count a bit.

"The previous quarterly record stands at 184,877. Troy Teslike estimates that in Q2, 198,000 is possible, which would support the thesis that the goal is 200,000 - just another, symbolic milestone."
https://insideevs.com/news/515129/elon-musk-pushes-tesla-q2/
China sales in may up from April, but still less than Q1.  Still think they will get past 350k, but not as certain as crowd.

Likely that they keep pace in Q2 with the total they delivered in Q1, which was 180,000. But recent focus on the new Model S deliveries, expected to be several hundred a week, may have impacted the higher volume Model 3/Y.

"Tesla's second-quarter vehicle deliveries will likely be greater than the record 185,000 vehicles it delivered in Q1."

Lowering forecast a bit due to supply chain/missing part issues (https://electrek.co/2021/05/18/tesla-stuck-with-over-10000-cars-factory-hold-resulting-logistical-nightmare/).
The consensus among the equity analysts rating Tesla is that the company will deliver between 800-900k cars in 2021.
Q1 sales is 185,000 - double the previous Q. Expects 850,000 in 2021.
Reducing by 2% due to chip shortage issues
Shifting to a heavy bucket 5, on news Tesla's Q2 production capacity has been sold out. https://www.electrive.com/2021/05/07/tesla-q2-production-capacity-already-sold-out/

They produced over 175K in Q1. Q1 is a slow period
Q2 is likely to be close to Q1 - that is 325K
Q2 has to significantly under perform Q1
In terms of demand and economy - there is no reason demand wont be there.
Ford and Fm produce over 4M vehicles annually.
Chip shortages are of a concern, but Ford is only forecasting a 180K decrease in deliveries. that's a small number in terms of percent. 
So
185k in Q1 and no slow downs or issues I am aware of

"In total, then, Troy’s forecast pegs Q2 at 195,000 deliveries, 15,000 below my forecast of 210,000." Add the 184,000 from Q1 and you're well into the 350,000+ bucket. 
https://cleantechnica.com/2021/04/19/more-tesla-sales-forecasts-and-by-factory/
(185 K deliveries in Q1)  * 2 = 370 K  => more than 350 K, but not much

185k deliveries in Q1.  At same rate in Q2 this gives 370k for first half.
Delivery rate was only slightly up on 202 Q4.  There was a slow down in production during Q1 but total similar to Q4 so assume ramp up was partially absorbed by slow down, which means Q2 will increase, with some net off dur to slower production impacting lead time on deliveries for a bit of Q2. All in all it looks likely to get part 350k, barring some dramatic event.  But could be close to the threshold.

Although first quarter 2021 number of 185,000 points to a better than even odds of more than 350,000 for the first half, the lagged impact from chip shortage, Fremont plant temporary stoppage and port capacity issues pose a real risk to that number.
Coming back down 5, a lot can happen especially during COVID so don't want to be too confident.
Good Q1 numbers at 185K deliveries & positive economic outlook & demand or EVs, but some risks in Q2 of normal variation + impact of semiconductor shortages

La marca Tesla ha aumentado su popularidad a  largo de los años, lo que significa que la venta de sus autos también. Como marca quieren llegar a muchos lados por lo que han aumentado su número de tiendas y puntos de carga a lo largo del mundo significativamente. Por ejemplo, en noviembre del 2020, Tesla ya tenía mas de 20 mil puntos de carga. Es por esto que l número de autos también ha ido aumentando, según la misma marca, en el primer cuarto del 2020, ya han producido cerca de 180000 vehículos y se espera que este número aumente. Es por esto que creo que la probabilidad de que hayan más de 350000 es muy alta, y si esto no pasa, creo que por lo menos habrán más de 250000 autos Tesla.
Fuente 1: https://ir.tesla.com/press-release/tesla-q1-2021-vehicle-production-deliveries
Fuente 2: https://www.motorpasion.com/tesla/tesla-abre-estacion-supercargadores-grande-mundo-56-puntos-para-recargar-120-km-autonomia-cinco-minutos#:~:text=Tesla%20cuenta%20actualmente%20con%20m%C3%A1s,guerra%20entre%20Porsche%20y%20Tesla.

https://ir.tesla.com/press-release/tesla-q1-2021-vehicle-production-deliveries 185k deliveries in Q1.  180k production.  Sales have been good in China.
April 26 for Q1 earning update which will have more detail.
Problems with ramping up production in other countries and not yet clear how the semi conductor shortage will affect things. If deliver same again in Q2 then this would be 370k deliveries. There is talk of ramping up production, but you can’t deliver more than you sell.  Need to see revenue numbers in April 26 release.
Nudging back towards under 350K because Q1 might have been a pent up demand effect.

0. Average deliveries from last 2 quarters: Q4 2020 (180.6k),  Q1 2021 (184.8k) => 182.7k.
1. From Statista, there isn't much noticeable seasonal difference in Q1-Q2 deliveries. Numbers mostly stable or increasing.
2. Needs to deliver 65.2k to hit 250k, which is about 36% of the average for the past 2 quarters. Seems highly unlikely that deliveries would be hit this hard, biggest shock was about 30% (Q4 2018 to Q1 2019).
3. Tesla states that it is still ramping up models 3/Y production in it's factory in Shanghai, and planning to ramp up production for S/X. If this happens, it's likely that production numbers will increase, so the upper bracket should be higher than the 182k mentioned before. Let's say Tesla manages to increase it's throughput of installed capacity from ~70% (182.7k in a quarter / 1050000 per year) to 75% (196.9k), the upper bracket should be 196.9 + 184.8 = 381.7
4. Considering a 10% shock possible (more factories than in 2019, China stable on COVID and US expected to stabilize over coming months), lower would be 164.4k, putting total at 349.2k.
5. I'll just assign an uniform distribution over this (0.8k to 350k, 32.5k range -> ~2.5%) [1] Tesla Shareholder Deck Q4 2020 https://tesla-cdn.thron.com/static/1LRLZK_2020_Q4_Quarterly_Update_Deck_-_Searchable_LVA2GL.pdf?xseo=&response-content-disposition=inline%3Bfilename%3D%22TSLA-Q4-2020-Update.pdf%22
[2] Statista - Quarterly Tesla Vehicle Delivered https://www.statista.com/statistics/502208/tesla-quarterly-vehicle-deliveries/
Update based on latest production numbers. If the company can keep up its Q1 2021 numbers is likely it will reach >350k production.
For more than 5 years Q2 deliveries are more than Q1
185,000 deliveries in Q1 of 2021, which is well within range of what my (very simple) model suggested. Anything below 350,000 seems very unlikely now.

My q1 estimate was out by 20,000, so even if my Q2 estimate is accurate now which is doubtful given how big Q1 was, the total will be above 350k, so unless there was some reason to pull deliveries forward (3% chance) I am reappraising my forecast fairly dramatically.
184,800 in Q1. Expect it to grow in Q2, which easily passes 350k bucket. https://ir.tesla.com/press-release/tesla-q1-2021-vehicle-production-deliveries
Tesla delivered a little over 185,000 in q1 2021, more than it produced in the quarter. Highly likely it repeats or exceeds that number in Q2 2021, bringing the total for 1H 2021 to above 350,000.
As noted by @bobrown, Tesla announced higher deliveries for Q1 than forecast.

Probability: 5% chance of 150,000-250,000 vehicles, 45% chance of more than 250,000 but fewer than 
350,000 vehicles, and 50% chance of greater than 350,000 vehicles. Currently, Tesla is producing vehicles in their factory in Fremont, California, and their Gigafactory in 
Shanghai (“About Tesla”). Tesla’s 2020 Q4 report states that Tesla delivered 499,550 vehicles in 2020 (“Tesla Q4”). By the end of Q2 they had delivered 184,944 vehicles (“Q2 2020 Update”). Tesla anticipates that 270,000 Model 3s will be produced in Shanghai in 2021. This is approximately 22,500 model 3s per month produced in China, totaling around 135,000 cars produced in Q1 and Q2 in China alone (“Tesla Gigafactory Shanghai”). Al Root, writing for Barron’s, shares that Tesla’s vehicle production has risen 71% year over year in the fourth quarter, leading an analyst to support the claim that 870,000 deliveries are possible for 2021. “Wall Street analysts on average project deliveries of 797,000, up another 60% compared with 2020. More sales and production in China along with initial Cybertruck sales in the U.S. should propel sales in the new year” (Root). Tesla is also building plants to add additional production capacity: a Gigafactory in Germany, expected 
to open in summer 2021 (Schmitz), and Gigafactory Texas, located in Austin and expected to open in 
May 2021 (Lambert). Given these numbers, I predict that there is a 0% chance that they will deliver fewer than 150,000 vehicles in the first two quarters. There is a 5% chance they will deliver 150,000-250,000 vehicles. There is a 45% chance they will deliver 250,000-350,000. There is a 50% chance they will deliver more than 350,000 vehicles. Sources: “About Tesla.” Tesla. https://www.tesla.com/en_EU/about. Accessed March 6, 2021. Supply chain headwinds may restrict deliveries so increase the risk of falling short. But >350k should be achievable hence 70%

Hence, there are slightly less than even chances to meet the ambition.

The recent semiconductor shortage is projected to lead to 1 million fewer vehicles produced in the first half of 2021, which I estimate amounts to 1-2% of annual worldwide production.
Assuming 20% growth in the first half of 2021 compared to the second half of 2020, that puts us at 480k vehicles. Assuming no growth and 5% reduction in volume due to shortages, that would put us at 304k.

As we  are now in Feb, and there have been no issues with deliveries ruling out less than 150, and reducing 150-250 to a minimum, reallocating all to 350k. Current view is still just under 335k so should be close.

In the last two years Tesla had a significant decrease in deliveries in the first half of the following year[1]. In 2020 this can be contributed to Corona this should not have the same impact this year. In 2019 it was due to distribution problems. With the new factory in Shanghai the probability of something like this happening again should be significantly lower. Industry estimates for the whole year are in the range of 750 000 - 850 000[2]. Taking into account that deliveries in the second half of the are 30-50% higher than in the first half of the year[1] this leaves us with a range of 300 000 – 370 000 deliveries to reach the estimates. If we include higher estimates up to 930 000[3] the range expands to 400 000 deliveries in the first half year. [1] https://www.statista.com/statistics/502208/tesla-quarterly-vehicle-deliveries/
[2] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-tesla-research-idUSKBN29X1RJ
[3] https://www.tesmanian.com/blogs/tesmanian-blog/tesla-2021-financial-projections

My primary source was Tesla’s quarterly earnings disclosures on their investor relations page, which included information on vehicle production and deliveries (https://ir.tesla.com./). In 2020, Tesla came just short of their self-imposed projection of half a million deliveries, coming in at a record 499,550, with 320,163 of those happening in the second half of the year. In Q1, they fulfilled 88,496 orders, 90,891 in Q2, 139,593 in Q3, and 180,570 in Q4. Taking into consideration the 36% increase in deliveries from 2019 to 2020 - even with their main factory shutting down in mid-May due to covid-19, - and the 30% increase from Quarter 3 to Quarter 4, I felt confident that this rising trend would continue. One source projected that the company should be able to ship “more than 720,000 vehicles from its Fremont and Shanghai factories in 2021”, and confirmed the company will be opening two new factories in Berlin and Texas by the end of the year (https://arstechnica.com/cars/2021/01/tesla-delivered-a-record-500000-vehicles-in-2020/). While Tesla can be expected to deliver somewhere between 500,000 and 1,000,000 vehicles in 2021, no one is certain of just how many of those fulfillments will take place in the first half of the year versus the latter half. However, considering that in order to hit or exceed the 350,000 target the company would have to deliver a minimum of 175,000 in Q1 and Q2 - a lesser number than Q4 of 2020 -, I felt bold enough to predict that there is a 80% probability they will deliver 350,000 or more vehicles, a 20% chance they will deliver more than 250,000 but less than 350,000, and a 0% probability they will deliver 250,000 vehicles or less.

In the last half of 2020 Tesla delivered 139K in Q3 and 180K in Q4 for a total of 319 in the last half of 2020. In the fist half of 2020 the sales were low but spiked in the last half even during the COVID pandemic. Therefore, I think the first half of 2021 will continue with the trend seen at the end of 2020 and will show sales close to the last half of 2020.

Global shortage of computer chips used in cars.  I've lowered the possibility of production >350.000. Although I haven't found any articles mentioning Tesla specifically but I assume they will be hit by this eventually.

Tesla reported delivering 499,550 vehicles in 2020, with 139,300 in Q3 and 180,570 in Q4 (1).  There is optimism that Tesla's production will ramp up even more in 2021 (2).  Given these numbers, if I average Q3 & Q4 production pessimistically assuming they can maintain, but not significantly increase in 2021, I get 159,935 vehicles per quarter.  This would amount to 319,870 for the first half of 2021.  As such, I am updating my forecast, more probable that Tesla will hit more than 250,000 but fewer than 350,000.  I'm not convinced yet that they will reach 350,000 or more. (1) https://www.cnbc.com/2021/01/02/tesla-tsla-q4-2020-vehicle-delivery-and-production-numbers.html
(2) https://www.fool.com/investing/2021/01/05/why-teslas-deliveries-are-likely-to-soar-in-2021/
Shanghai will produce both M3 and MY. MY standard range and RWD will sell very well.

I don't expect huge growth--all their mass-market cars are on the market now, and they are mostly phased out of tax credits--but I expect continued growth and the outside chance of public policy change in their favor given the new administration.

Tesla's Q3 and Q4 numbers are 140k and 181k respectively. Typically there's a small seasonal drop off between Q4 and Q1, so I'd be surprised if they could average over 175k for the next 2 quarters to hit 350k or more. I'm putting most of my stock in the 250-350 range.

Links with 2021 forecasts:
_https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-tsla-1m-cars-per-year-2021-wall-st/
_https://oilprice.com/Energy/Energy-General/Tesla-Is-On-Track-To-Deliver-1-Million-EVs-In-2021.html Own modeling:
_Used historical data to determine mean quarterly growth rate and std since 2016
_Quarterly growth rate has been quite stable since then (average of 30%).
_Ran simulations for 2021 with normally distributed growth rates (mean of 30% with std as my "uncertainty" regarding that rate) and a starting point of 180,570 delivered vehicles in Q4 of 2020 and counted how often the result fell within respective ranges 
_Will update when Q1 2021 results are in This is the first time I am using a model based on simulations like that and I really have no idea what will come of it! If you guys have any experience regarding this topic, please let me know if you have any tips. Cheers!

So as with every year with Tesla there's a delivery hit that they take in Q1 due to the push to get year end deliveries in place. last year this was a 21% delivery reduction from the Q4 numbers to the Q1 numbers.
Applying this % to the Q4 numbers gives a Q1 expected 142k deliveries and it's worth noting that the Q4 2019 numbers were not beaten again until Q3 2020.    Taking an external view there are still many issues around COVID that may impact production and delivery and with berlin not really ramping production until the end of the year there's not much additional capacity for growth until then. Further according to the battery day presentations there's significant production upgrades that Tesla need to make to the lines - doing this without impacting delivery expansion will be very difficult and it makes sense for the changes to be made earlier rather than later.  Overall it's going to be close to the 350k but probably not over that amount.  https://ir.tesla.com/press-release/tesla-q4-2020-vehicle-production-deliveries

Update from previous forecast.
Taking in Q4 2020 deliveries (180K) and taking into account increased production expected for 2021:
decreased change of >150k deliveries to 0% - due to the long timeframe to completion, expected deliveries in the timeframe, and the fact that there are multiple production facilities running.
decreased change of >150k <250k to 1% - same reason as above although I wont completely rule it out for example due to issues with production or suppliers, or regulatory issues (especially considering the US - China trade war)
decrease change of  >250k <350k to 20%. same possible issues as above
increased change of >350 to 79% expected factory production should be above this threshold

There are seasonal effects so I look at past Q1 and Q2:
Q1 2020: 88,496
Q2 2019: 95,200 (used 2019 due to COVID shutdowns affecting 2020 numbers)
Low end projection if 2021 deliveries match 2020: 183,696 High end projection:
Total annual capacity across Fremont and Shanghai is 840,000, which is quarterly capacity of 210,000. I know plants are not operating at full capacity but by using the full capacity number it can include possible production from Shanghai Model Y and Berlin Model Y, which are expected to start deliveries in 2021. High end projection over 2 quarters = 420,000. Averaging low end (183,696) and high end (420,000) = 301,848, comfortably in the middle of third bucket. https://tesla-cdn.thron.com/static/HZTKGL_TSLA_Update_Letter_2020-1Q_VGVL6F.pdf

Even with severe Covid disruptions Tesla managed to produce 82,000 vehicles in q2 20.  They also managed to produce 145,000 in q3 20, so they clearly have the ability to produce more than 350,000 vehicles. If Covid suddenly caused more issues next year, by taking the worst quarter you would get a production of 164,000. So if you remove Covid from the equation for the moment, the question becomes what will demand for Teslas do in the next six months. Annualising 2020 YTD you get 425,000, and that includes two covid affected quarters, but you could argue that Q3 deliveries were inflated as a result. 425,000 deliveries is probably very conservative, as in their late October investor call they were still optimistic they had a chance of hitting 500,000, so 475k as a baseline seems fair. 475k annualised would imply a 47% increase in sales to get to 350, a 5% increase to 250 and a 37% drop in sales to get to 150,000, in a very short time period (June 21) . Happy to rule out 150k, but will allocate 2% for some extreme circumstances, egregious fraud/safety issues etc.
150-250k assumes up to only 5% growth. Given the company has been gearing up for "in the vicinty" 850k to 1m deliveries in 2021 (investor call oct 20), and you would expect them to have decent visibility over the next 6 months of demand, I will attribute 8% (+3% for an aggressive resurgence of Covid that impacts production materially).
Turning to the most bullish case, 350k assumes that the company's growth and production play out as they expect without anything going wrong. So taking those assumptions of 180k deliveries in q4, that would equate to 360k in H1 21. In the US market, given delivery times are being pushed out until Mar 21 for some models that would suggest this is feasible, but demand in China and Europe seems to be stagnating. But stagnating does not mean dropping and the US is still the most important market so I will allocate 33% to this case.
Leaving 54% for the remaining case.
I drive Tesla and EV will boost in Europe

Recent trend suggests something around 260-300k but Q3 looks like a solid one time bump

Baseline: Current production capacity is 840,000 cars annually. The aim is to deliver 500,000 cars 2020, and with 320k cars delivered the first 3 quarters the look like they will land just shy of 450k. A capacity of 420k for the H1 of 2021 is therefore my baseline.  In addition, the New Texas plant could start production, in May 2021 while production in the new gigafactory in Berlin is also expected to start 2021, however, more unknown how this latter plan will impact production capacity first half of 2021. Based on this I push my estimate on the capacity to 500k H1 2021.  The question is whether demand will follow production capacity. According to a number of different sources EV demand growth is expected to remain intact indicating that if there is supply it will be sold. There are of course a number of complicating factors as more supply in the market coming from Volkswagen, the Chinese players etc., but for now I am assuming that the brand power of Tesla will attract enough demand.  Sources
https://electrek.co/2020/09/16/tesla-gigafactory-texas-plans-revealed/
https://thedriven.io/2020/11/25/teslas-berlin-giga-factory-will-be-biggest-battery-factory-in-world/
https://www.fool.com/investing/2020/10/25/could-tesla-deliveries-surge-70-next-year/
https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/world-electric-vehicles-ev-batteries-and-materials-markets-2020-2025-structural-ev-demand-growth-to-remain-intact-amid-the-covid-19-outbreak-1029687425?op=1
in Q3/20 Tesla sold almost 140k cars.

They're averaging just under 110k per quarter over the last 4 quarters. Which would be 220k over first half of the year. But per their latest Q3 report they recently increased capacity and their listed annual vehicle capacity totals 840k. If they were able to produce that full capacity that would be 420k per half year or 210k per quarter. Q3 this year they delivered 140k (which could be partly from coronavirus delays). In Q3 2019 their listed annual capacity was 590k. That would have been 295k units over the first half of the year. Dividing their actual first half deliveries by capacity is 180k/295k, which is 0.61. Multiplying that by the Q3 2020 listed capacity of 840k is 512k per year, which would translate to 256k units. I think however that the coronavirus depressed their deliveries in the first two quarters of this year, so I would expect higher. Based on those rough numbers I'm going to go fairly confident on 250 to 350, and lean toward bucket 4 or bucket 2. Deliveries over time: https://www.statista.com/statistics/502208/tesla-quarterly-vehicle-deliveries/ Talking about Musk's projection (I currently consider 850k to 1 million to be a bit too optimistic): https://www.tesmanian.com/blogs/tesmanian-blog/tesla-q3-2020-earnings-call-850k-1m-deliveries-in-2021-not-far-off-per-elon-musk Q3 info from shareholder deck here: https://ir.tesla.com/

Expect strong demand for electric vehicles, especially with the Biden administration.

The rate of growth is accelerating for demand for electric vehicles in general, with a larger focus on electrical vehicle research and general trend towards them. With Tesla expanding into China for production, by extension, there would seem to be much more demand in China (a huge electric vehicle market as well). However, potential trade embargoes with China hangs by a thread. With additional attention paid to climate change and the detrimental effects, there will be a large push towards the electric vehicles market, with Tesla leading the way in both funding (via addition to the S&P 500 and increases in its share price largely driven by this event) as well as first-mover advantage.
